context: you are delivering tests via a drone for a virus that has a 98.6% survival rate????? madness..
First texas turns blue and then this!! They are getting smart

replies.context: Sure they are smart.  Shutting down the mainstay of their economy.  Now that is really encouraging.
Yup, life before liberty. that is how it is written in the declaration of independence.
I must have missed something about TX elections. They vote Trump for president, Republican for the Senate, and 22 out of 36 seats in the house were Republican. I would not call that turning blue.

context: I wouldn't touch that test or ''cure'' for covid with 20 foot pole!
And how can you be sure this is not a way for Bill Gates, and the Dr. Fauci to further spread Corona to you so they can be the Saviors?

replies.context: Because there are far simpler and more effective ways to spread a virus than this.

context:
How stupid..hurry and deliver test, then send it back in the mail..get results 10 days later.
How about test and return by drone, same day results?

replies.context: Well it is really about automation to eliminate more employees. As the governments start mandating increasing wages to employees more automation goes into play. As the wages increase the employee costs go up and automation becomes ever more attractive. Look at the big stores, they already use self checkout lanes  and only a handful of cashiers now. then at night the cleaning robots come out. They even started using robots to check inventory and even do limiting restocking too. Amazon is heavily automated in their warehouses.

context: This is just a bunch of boys playing with their toys.  What a waste of time and money.

I thought there was a law against surprise bills from medical insurance? Remember that helicopter ride during the emergency that cost you $50K.
Why do I think that this is a mini version of this?

replies.context: The drone service is donated by Walmart and the Covid-19 tests are donated by Quest Diagnostics.
the test may be free.. the results are not.. someone is getting paid somewhere or they wouldn't be doing it.. don't be naive..

context: Remember all those stories about how Amazon, and others were going to be delivering with drones, lol? I said at the time it was all a PR campaign, to get free publicity.  And, now it is clear that was true. Perhaps someday this may happen on a limited basis But as a pilot, I can tell you weather is far to unpredictable in most of the country for that to be a viable method of operation.

replies.context:
Would the drones benfit from flying lower to the ground than you would in a plane?  Is the weather a little more predictable lower to the ground than what you'd run into at thousands of feet of elevation?
btw, I obviously have no idea how this works, it's an honest question, so please don't just laugh at me for being meteorologically (sp?) challenged.
In an urban area flying low is good idea because tall buildings will create a thermal effect similar to mountain ridges at higher altitudes.

context: Seems to be rather elaborate and unreliable. Without the supervision of a technician can we trust the results? What if someone else takes the test, not the intended person? What if the family dog attacks the drone or chews the test before it can be used? Or a child picks it up and plays with it before an adult knows its there or retrieves it? What if the drone gets stuck on power lines or trees?  What if the drone is launched with low charge? I've heard of Larger birds of prey plucking a drone out of the sky. Or someone decides to blast one out of the sky. No, not probable but eventually, these sorts of things will happen or have happened and need to be considered.

Quest Diagnostics is a poorly managed company. They administer the testing for our insurance and repeatedly have messed up the reporting on their own website. Spent literally days trying to get it fixed or we would be billed $500.00 in extra cost, all due to their own mistakes.
